awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2021: Deciphering grammatical rules of notochord enhancers and their role in notochord development in Ciona intestinalis
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2021, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the Fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. Early developmental stage cells differentiate into all of the cell types present in an organism’s adult body. These transitions are the result of changes in gene expression and the subsequent changes in RNA and protein products. Enhancers are genetic elements that encode instructions for the location and timing of gene expression, which ensures that tissues are created at the right time and place during development; variations in enhancer sequences are associated with outcomes that impact organisms in many ways. However, the millions of enhancer sequence variations have made it difficult to determine causal links between enhancer genotype and its expression (phenotype). The Fellow will investigate how control of gene expression is encoded within enhancers and the links between enhancers and these organismal traits. Research findings will be communicated by the Fellow to diverse audiences through mentorship of undergraduate student researchers and public science outreach programs.

This research will examine tissue-specific enhancers in the notochord, an embryonic tissue that provides structural support and developmental patterning signals to adjacent tissues. To study how notochord activity is encoded within notochord-specific enhancers, the Fellow will create synthetic notochord enhancer variant reporter DNA constructs, which will be introduced into fertilized eggs of the sea squirt, Ciona intestinalis (Ciona). Ciona embryos will be screened for enhancer activity by measuring fluorescent reporter activity with microscopy and unique DNA barcode expression with RNA sequencing. The Fellow will use data generated from enhancer activity screens to identify common features of notochord enhancers. These notochord enhancer features will then be used to inform an existing computational pipeline to identify potential notochord enhancers within the Ciona genome. Additionally, the Fellow will use targeted gene editing in fertilized Ciona eggs to examine how genetic variations within notochord-specific enhancers impact gene expression (of genes controlled by selected enhancers) and notochord development (phenotype). Data generated from this research will be incorporated into interactive guest lectures for undergraduates; the Fellow will also gain training and experience in university-level teaching and mentorship, computational methods to analyze large data sets, and scientific communication.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A major question within biology is how genomic DNA, which is the same in all non-reproductive cells of an organism, encodes the instructions for creating numerous cell types with distinct forms and functions present within the body. The establishment and maintenance of cell identity and function is determined by which genes are turned on or off in a cell, called gene expression. Gene expression itself is controlled by DNA elements called enhancers, whose activity is controlled by the binding of activating or repressive transcription factor proteins. Thus, tissue-specific (cell type) enhancers are critical for ensuring that genes are correctly expressed at the right time and place during development to create and maintain the correct cell types and cell numbers for survival and homeostasis. However, it is unclear how enhancers are encoded within our genomes and how genetic variations within enhancers might lead to changes in gene expression and subsequent individual trait differences, disease, or organismal diversity.

This project used embryos of the sea squirt (Ciona), a marine invertebrate with a simple genome, as a model system to study (1) how tissue-specific enhancers are encoded in genomes and to (2) understand how genotype variation within enhancers leads to phenotype outcomes. Previous studies suggested that a combination of at least two ETS and one ZicL transcription factor binding site (TFBS) sequences are necessary, but not entirely sufficient to encode notochord-specific enhancer activity. We used a massively parallel reporter assay to conduct a genome-wide screen of potential notochord enhancer sequences containing at least two ETS and one ZicL TFBS. Here, a library of 90 putative enhancer sequences were paired with a minimal promoter, a green fluorescent reporter gene, and an average of six unique transcribable barcodes per putative enhancer. We found that thirty-nine sequences were active enhancers, but most of the screened genomic regions are not notochord enhancers (81/90), confirming that presence ETS and ZicL is not sufficient to encode notochord activity. Additionally, there was no clear pattern of common features in the few sequences that showed notochord-specific enhancer activity.  Next, we sought to determine if additional TFBS might be required for notochord enhancer activity. To test this, we dissected an enhancer controlling expression of the notochord-specific gene, Brachyury, to determine its functional sequences. We identified potential TFBS within the Brachyury enhancer; to determine which TFBS were necessary and sufficient for enhancer activity within the notochord, we created and screened a plasmid enhancer reporter library where the DNA sequences outside of the putative TFBS were randomized. We found that this Brachyury enhancer is controlled through binding site sequences for the transcription factors ETS, ZicL, FoxA2, and Brachyury. Additionally, a combination of these TFBS is found in mouse Brachyury enhancers, suggesting a conserved notochord enhancer logic.

While we were able to expand on our understanding of putative TFBS present in notochord enhancers, we still lacked knowledge of common features outside of TFBS sequences that could encode tissue specificity, like the order, orientation, and spacing of TFBS within the enhancer sequence. To address this knowledge gap, we created a new massively parallel reporter assay approach that enables us to examine enhancer activity across the entire embryo at the single cell level. Previous iterations of massively parallel reporter assays in whole embryos tell you if a sequence is an enhancer and its activity level within the entire embryo, but this approach lacks spatial information like what cell types an enhancer is active in. Our new approach combines single cell RNA sequencing, which is used to identify cell type, with enhancer plasmid reporter libraries to determine cell-type specific enhancer activity readouts.  We are currently using this new approach to identify patterns in notochord specific enhancers through an unbiased genome-wide screen of putative notochord enhancers. We are using whole embryo single cell ATAC-Sequencing to identify differentially accessible chromatin regions present in notochord cells compared to the whole embryo as these regions could contain notochord enhancers. We will screen these putative enhancers for notochord-specific activity and identify shared features that could act to encode notochord-specific enhancers. We will then use genome editing to create mutations within these notochord-specific enhancer shared features to determine how genotype impacts gene expression and phenotype.

The PI mentored two undergraduate students though the Biology Undergraduate and Master's Mentorship Program (BUMMP) at UCSD and participated as a poster judge for the BUMMP mentee poster presentation. The PI trained and mentored two high school summer students from Mexico in the sponsoring scientist’s lab as part of the ENLACE program at UCSD. The PI gave a virtual guest lecture to an introductory biology course at CSULA about molecular biology techniques, using findings from this project as examples of how molecular techniques are used in research. Lastly, the PI visited the Feaster Charter School in Chula Vista to help facilitate an interactive Ciona development laboratory demonstration.

 


Last Modified: 09/29/2024
Modified by: Krissie Tellez
